summary: This is a declaration by the administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program (EVCP) in support of a motion to quash a subpoena from Ghislaine Maxwell. The declaration argues that confidentiality is a cornerstone of the program, essential for victims of sexual abuse to participate, and that disclosing program documents would violate court-approved protocols and harm the program's integrity.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case who has issued a subpoena to the EVCP administrator for program documents, which this declaration seeks to quash.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased individual whose estate established the EVCP to resolve claims of sexual abuse against him and related parties.

persons.name: Kenneth R. Feinberg
persons.context: Co-designed the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program and testified in the U.S. Virgin Islands Probate Court about the program's confidentiality requirements.

connections.description: Maxwell is a defendant in a case related to Epstein, and the EVCP was established to resolve claims against Epstein and related individuals, which includes her.

events.title: Establishment of Epstein Victims' Compensation Program
events.description: A litigation-alternative program was established to confidentially resolve claims of sexual abuse against Jeffrey Epstein, his estate, and related individuals and entities.

events.title: Filing of Declaration to Quash Subpoena
events.description: The EVCP administrator files this declaration in support of a motion to quash a subpoena from Ghislaine Maxwell for EVCP documents.

keyFacts: The Epstein Victims' Compensation Program (EVCP) was designed as a confidential, non-adversarial alternative to litigation for victims of sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein and related parties.
Confidentiality is described as a 'cornerstone' and 'absolute imperative' of the EVCP, critical for victims of sexual abuse, particularly those distrustful of the justice system, to participate.
The EVCP Protocol was approved by the Probate Court of the U.S. Virgin Islands and grants the administrator complete autonomy over claim determinations.
Ghislaine Maxwell has subpoenaed the EVCP administrator for program documents, which this declaration argues would violate confidentiality, court orders, and public policy.
The declaration corrects what it states are inaccurate characterizations in Maxwell's motion regarding how the EVCP Protocol evaluates claims.
